Yup, it is.  The video game industry has been locking out other territoies 
for years, by both physical and electronic means.  The DVD industry took a 
cue from them.  At one point Sony was attempting to make it illegal for 
anyone to modify a piece of consumer electronic equipment (for any reason, 
not just to defeat copy protection or a region lockout) other than an 
authorized dealer.  Scary stuff.



>The player I have, if anyone wants
>to know, is Panasonic DV31 (or something like that. oops!).
>
>I wish we didn't have the stupid codes because I thought DVDs would rid of
>the pal and ntsc incompatibilities.  So now it's that AND a code.

     The real irony with Region coding is that they were too cheap to make 
more than 9 regions (10 if you count region '0').  The region codes are 
split between countries that have different TV standards.  For example: 
Brazil and Australia are both region 4, but Oz uses a slightly different 
form of PAL than the UK and Brazil uses PAL-M, which is closer to NTSC (and 
in fact, Region 4 disks sold in Brazil are NTSC versions).
  Whats amusing is that The UK and Japan are both region 2.  The UK has very 
strict import laws when it comes to DVD's (some of it is due to different 
censorship ratings): It's illegal to sell non region-2 PAL DVD's in stores 
and ordering overseas for a Region 1 DVD could get it confiscated by the 
postal authorities.  The region codes were set up in part to avoid the legal 
hassle of someone purchaasing a DVD with objectionable content from another 
region  (which might not be *as* objectionable in another country).  The 
twist is that almost all modern PAL DVD players can convert NTSC to PAL on 
the fly, so it's quite easy for someone in the UK to watch some tentacle 
rape hentai without any technical hitches whatsoever.

     A good number of Chinese-made cheap DVD players have flooded the market 
in the past 2 years.  Almost all of them can covert PAL to NTSC (and vice 
versa) on the fly (needed because China uses both TV standards), be set to 
Region 0 (region bypass) and some even defeat Region Code Enhancement (RCE, 
I can explain this if you're unsure as to what it is).  Regions really 
*aren't* an issue if you know what player to buy.  Research before you 
purcase!
